questions.text: Lymph from a cancerous breast primarily drains into which of the following nodes? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Anterior (pectoral) nodes

 

Explanation: 

 

The lymphatic drainage of the breast primarily flows into the anterior (pectoral) group of axillary lymph nodes. These nodes are positioned along the lateral thoracic vessels at the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle. Approximately 75% of the lymph from the breast tissue drains into the axillary nodes, with the anterior group receiving the major portion. This makes the anterior (pectoral) nodes the first-line lymph nodes to receive drainage from cancerous breast tissue, particularly from the upper lateral quadrant where breast cancer most commonly occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Apical nodes: Located at the apex of the axilla, these nodes receive lymph secondarily after it has passed through other axillary node groups. They're not the primary recipients of breast lymph drainage.
  • Option C. Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes: These nodes receive about 20% of breast lymphatic drainage, primarily from the medial quadrants of the breast, but are not the main drainage pathway.
  • Option D. Supraclavicular nodes: These become involved primarily in advanced cases of breast cancer. They receive lymph only after it has passed through multiple other node groups.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anterior (pectoral) lymph nodes are the primary recipients of lymphatic drainage from the breast, making them crucial for early detection and staging of breast malignancy.

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibers

questions.text: Identify the correct order of layers incised while performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

 

The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

  • Deep fascia is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds muscles, bones, and neurovascular structures. It creates the compartments in limbs, and in compartment syndrome, it is this fascial layer that is primarily responsible for the elevated pressures.
  • For a fasciotomy, the incision goes through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and, crucially, the deep fascia. This releases the increased pressure in the muscle compartment and restores blood flow.
  • The procedure is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, subcutaneous fat, and superficial and deep fascia.
  • The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia.
  • This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

 

 

Educational Objective:


During a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the incision must pass through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia to adequately decompress the affected muscle compartments.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: Sarcoma Botryoides most commonly arises from? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagina

 

Explanation:

 

Sarcoma Botryoides, a subtype of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, typically presents as a polypoid mass with a grape-like appearance. It is the most common malignant tumor of the vagina in children and is also the second most common site for embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma after the head and neck region, particularly in the first five years of life. While it can occur in the cervix, it is less common there compared to the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterus: Sarcoma Botryoides can occur here, but it is much less common than in the vagina.

 

Option B. Cervix: This tumor can arise in the cervix, but it is significantly less common than in the vagina.

 

Option D. Vulva: This is not a typical site for Sarcoma Botryoides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for Sarcoma Botryoides in the female genital tract is the vagina.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a palpable lump in her breast. Which of the following investigations cannot be used to rule out malignancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PET scan

 

In the evaluation of a breast lump or any suspicious symptoms, the triple assessment method is used. It involves clinical assessment, radiological examination, and cytological or histological examination. The combination of these three modalities has a high positive predictive value of 99.99% to exclude breast cancer.

 

Positron emission tomography (PET) scans are not typically used as part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. PET scans use a radioactive tracer to produce detailed images of the body and are more commonly used to evaluate cancers that have spread to other parts of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiological investigations: Radiological investigations such as mammography or ultrasound are commonly used as part of the triple assessment method to evaluate a breast lump. These tests help to identify any suspicious areas in the breast tissue that may require further evaluation with a biopsy.

 

Option C. Clinical examination: Clinical examination, including physical examination and assessment of medical history, is an important part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. This can help to identify any specific risk factors for breast cancer and assess the characteristics of the lump, such as size, shape, and texture.

 

Option D. Histology and cytology: Histology and cytology are essential parts of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of the lump helps to establish a definitive diagnosis and determine whether the lump is benign or malignant. The sample is then examined under a microscope to determine the characteristics of the cells and provide further information about the tumor, such as the stage and grade.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

 

Explanation:

 

Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

 

Types of Gallstones:

 

  • Cholesterol Stones: These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • Pigment Stones: Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • Mixed Stones: These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.

 

Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.

 

Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: Identify the following image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ranula

 

The given clinical scenario and the image showing a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth points to a diagnosis of a Ranula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A benign tumor made up of blood vessels, often appearing as a birthmark or red growth.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system, often present at birth. It presents as a posterior neck swelling.

 

Option C. Branchial cyst: A congenital epithelial cyst that arises from remnants of the branchial arches, usually presenting as a neck lump.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Uro bags - collection of urine.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: In a patient with thyroid malignancy, serum calcitonin was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid, which produce the hormone calcitonin. Elevated serum calcitonin is a characteristic marker for MTC. In addition to calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can also be elevated in MTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because follicular thyroid carcinoma typically does not elevate calcitonin. Instead, it may show elevated serum thyroglobulin.

 

Option B. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because papillary thyroid carcinoma is associated with elevated serum thyroglobulin, not calcitonin.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: This is incorrect as anaplastic carcinoma is an aggressive form of thyroid cancer that does not produce calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is the thyroid cancer associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels, distinguishing it from other types of thyroid malignancies.

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison liquefactive necrosis

 

Management Emergency stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment usually after 3-6 months elective reconstruction esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done for the treatment of Pilonidal sinus as shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transposition flap

 

The image provided shows a surgical procedure used to treat a pilonidal sinus. The procedure depicted is a Limberg flap, also known as a rhomboid flap. In this technique, a rhomboid-shaped piece of tissue adjacent to the excision site is cut and transposed to cover the wound created after the excision of the pilonidal sinus. This movement of tissue from the side to the gap is characteristic of a transposition flap. The Limberg flap is effective for ensuring tension-free closure and reducing the recurrence of the pilonidal sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial flap: This type of flap involves tissue that has a specific blood supply along its axis, which is not depicted in the image provided.

 

Option B. Rotation flap: A rotation flap involves rotating tissue around a pivot point to cover a defect. The image shows transposition rather than rotation.

 

Option C. Advancement flap: This involves moving tissue forward to cover a defect, typically in a straight line, which is not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Limberg flap, used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus, is a type of transposition flap where tissue from the adjacent side is cut, rotated, and used to close the defect created by the excision of the pilonidal sinus.

questions.text: Identify the most important risk factor for acute mastitis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cracked nipple
 

The most important risk factor for acute mastitis is the presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples. These openings provide a direct entry point for bacteria, primarily Staphylococcus aureus, which commonly inhabits the oropharynx of the nursing infant. This condition often arises during the first month of breastfeeding when the nipples are most vulnerable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Massage: While massage can sometimes be recommended to alleviate symptoms of engorgement or blocked ducts, improper or overly vigorous massage is not a significant risk factor for developing acute mastitis.

 

Option B. Breast engorgement: Breast engorgement can lead to blocked ducts and potentially contribute to mastitis if milk is not effectively removed, but it is not the most important risk factor compared to cracked nipples.

 

Option C. Lactation failure: Lactation failure can cause issues such as milk stasis and engorgement, which might predispose to infection. However, it is not as direct a risk factor as cracked nipples, which provide a clear pathway for bacterial entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cracks and fissures in the nipples is the most important risk factor for acute mastitis due to the direct pathway it provides for bacterial entry.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube. On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethral injury 

 

  • The image provided is a radiographic image, from a retrograde urethrogram, is of bulbar urethral injury with stricture. 
  • This injury occurs in the bulbar part of the urethra, which is located between the penile urethra and the membranous urethra. This type of injury can result from trauma, typically blunt perineal trauma, and can be identified on imaging by contrast extravasation or interruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethral injury: This type of injury occurs in the membranous portion of the urethra, which is the shortest, least dilatable, and most fixed part of the urethra. It's often associated with pelvic fractures and can be identified by an abnormal urethrogram.

 

Option C. Penile stricture: A penile stricture is a narrowing of the penile urethra. It would be visualized on a urethrogram as a narrowed segment but would not show the contrast extravasation typically seen in traumatic injuries.

 

Option D. Prostate hyperplasia: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is an enlargement of the prostate gland and can cause obstruction of the urethral passage. On imaging, BPH would not present as a urethral injury but could show an enlarged prostate and possibly a post-void residual.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A bulbar urethral injury through radiographic imaging shows contrast extravasation or interruption in the bulbar urethra, indicative of trauma to this specific area.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

 

The CT scan image shows a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is a type of intracranial hemorrhage characterized by a crescent-shaped bleed along the brain's surface, often resulting from head trauma. In the case of traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, the primary concern is to stop the bleeding and manage intracranial pressure.

 

Vitamin K is an essential factor in the clotting cascade and is used to promote clotting and reduce bleeding. It is especially useful if the patient is suspected to be on anticoagulant therapy, as it helps counteract the effects of such medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots in ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction. Administering it in the context of a hemorrhagic stroke would worsen the bleeding.

 

Option B. Retiplase: Similar to alteplase, retiplase is another thrombolytic agent and is contraindicated in cases of hemorrhage due to its potential to exacerbate bleeding.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation. Giving heparin in a situation of intracranial hemorrhage would further inhibit clotting and worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: A dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure undergoes cystoscopy. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoscopy with removal of tumor

 

The patient, a dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure, undergoes cystoscopy which reveals a bladder growth. Benzidine exposure is a known risk factor for bladder cancer. The appropriate initial management for a bladder tumor identified on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal of the tumor, also known as transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT). This procedure allows for both the resection of the tumor and a biopsy to determine the stage and grade of the cancer.

 

  • If the tumor is non-muscle invasive (T1), intravesical BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guerin) therapy is administered to reduce the risk of recurrence.
  • If the tumor is muscle-invasive (T2 or worse), more radical treatment such as radical cystectomy (removal of the bladder) may be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV BCG: This is incorrect as initial treatment. BCG is used as an adjuvant therapy after TURBT for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Option C. TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate): This is incorrect as TURP is a procedure used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), not bladder tumors.

 

Option D. Radical cystectomy: This is not the initial step. It is considered if the tumor is muscle-invasive or in cases of high-risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of a bladder tumor seen on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal (TURBT) to both resect the tumor and obtain a biopsy for staging and grading.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen after bariatric gastric bypass surgery? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is a common bariatric surgery, second to sleeve gastrectomy. The most common deficiency observed after this procedure is iron deficiency anemia. This occurs because the stomach, which plays a role in converting dietary iron to its absorbable form, is partially bypassed. Reduced stomach acid production post-surgery also impairs iron absorption. This is particularly concerning for menstruating women, who are at higher risk for iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin D: After a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, there's a reduced absorptive surface area and altered gut flora, leading to decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin D. However, this deficiency is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option B. Deficiency of calcium: Reduced stomach acid production post-gastric bypass can affect the solubilization of calcium salts, leading to decreased calcium absorption. This deficiency is often associated with vitamin D deficiency but is not as common as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Protein-calorie malnutrition: After bariatric surgery, especially gastric bypass, the reduced stomach size can lead to decreased food intake. If protein intake is not adequate, it can lead to protein-calorie malnutrition, particularly in the early post-operative period. However, this is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common deficiency observed after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriches syndrome.
  • Leriches syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor size <4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

 

Options B, C, and D are contraindications for breast conservative surgery, whereas option A is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery.

 

Breast-conserving surgery, also known as lumpectomy or partial mastectomy, is a suitable option when the primary tumor in the breast is relatively small (typically less than 4 cm). Presence of N1 disease (ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph node metastasis) is not a contra-indicated. However, since LN are already involved, a sentinel lymph biopsy is not needed, and up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast: Breast-conserving surgery aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the breast tissue as possible. If the tumor size exceeds the size of the breast, it may not be feasible to perform breast-conserving surgery, as there would be insufficient healthy breast tissue remaining.

 

Option C. Previous chest irradiation: Previous chest irradiation, especially at high doses, can affect the breast tissue's tolerance to additional radiation. It may limit the use of breast-conserving surgery due to concerns about radiation toxicity.

 

Option D. Presence of multiple tumors: Breast-conserving surgery is typically performed for a single primary tumor in the breast. If there are multiple tumors in different areas of the breast, it may not be suitable for breast-conserving surgery, as it may be challenging to achieve clear margins and preserve breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Breast conservative surgery involves the removal of the primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, followed by adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes through a separate axillary incision.

 

Absolute contraindications for breast conservative surgery include pregnancy, persistently positive margins, multicentric lumps, diffuse microcalcification, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Relative contraindications include active systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, a large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump), known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), multifocal disease, and prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast.

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

 

The image displays a Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed drainage system used in post-surgical procedures. This device comprises a flexible bulb connected to tubing, creating negative pressure to gently suction fluid from the wound or surgical site. The bulb can be compressed and then sealed to initiate suction, allowing controlled drainage and reducing the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Romovac drain: Romovac drains are commonly used after various surgical procedures, including abdominal surgeries, breast surgeries, orthopedic surgeries, and others. They are also utilized in the treatment of abscesses and some types of traumatic injuries. They are a closed drainage system.

 

 

Option C. Minivac drain (Mini in size): A closed suction drain is placed under your skin during surgery. This drain removes any blood or other fluids that might build up in this area.

 

 

Option D. Corrugated drain: Corrugated drains are intended for open passive drainage, used in situations where wounds must be kept open. They are placed directly into the wounds left to heal by secondary intent. 

 

 

Educational Objective : 

 

The Jackson-Pratt drain is a closed drainage system that uses gentle suction to remove fluids from surgical sites, helping prevent fluid accumulation and reducing infection risk.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene 

 

This is a serious bacterial infection characterized by necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineal, genital, or perianal regions. It often presents with rapid onset, pain, swelling, and crepitus due to gas formation, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. The infection can spread quickly, and early surgical intervention is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gas gangrene: Also known as clostridial myonecrosis, gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium species and is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and production of gas, which can be palpable as crepitus

 

Option C. Wet gangrene: This form of gangrene arises when the blood flow to an area is lost, and a bacterial infection develops. It typically affects extremities and is associated with swelling, blistering, and a wet appearance due to pus.

 

Option D. Scrotal hematoma: This is a collection of blood within the scrotal sac but does not involve an infection. It may occur after trauma or surgery. While it can cause swelling and discoloration, it does not present with the same level of systemic illness seen in gangrenous conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fourniers gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fourniers gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Identify the image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

 

The image provided likely shows a neonate with a congenital defect characterized by the intestines and other abdominal organs extending outside of the abdominal cavity but contained within a sac composed of peritoneum and amnion. 

 

This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where the intestines, liver, and occasionally other organs remain outside of the abdomen in a sac because of a failure in the normal return of intestines and other contents back to the abdominal cavity during development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urachal cyst: This is a remnant of the embryonic connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord, which usually closes before birth. A cyst can form if this connection does not close properly. It typically does not involve protrusion of abdominal contents.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with cyst: This option isn't a standard term in medical diagnosis. An omphalocele does not typically have a cyst, but rather a sac that is formed from the peritoneum and amnion, containing the herniated organs.

 

Option D. Umbilical adenoma: This is not a recognized condition related to abdominal wall defects in neonates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Omphalocele is a birth defect characterized by an abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal contents into an overlying sac due to a failure of normal return of contents during embryonic development.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the bodys ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: An Intraoperative image of MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy) is shown. What nerve is marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Median pectoral nerve

 

During a modified radical mastectomy, careful identification and preservation of nerves is crucial to avoid postoperative complications. In this question, the nerve marked runs on the pectoralis minor muscle. This positioning is characteristic of the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies both the pectoralis minor and major muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and runs along the chest wall, passing vertically on the serratus anterior muscle, not the pectoralis minor.

 

Option B. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior chest wall and runs close to the latissimus dorsi, not along the pectoralis minor.

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: This nerve innervates muscles such as the subscapularis, teres major, and latissimus dorsi. It is positioned more posteriorly and does not typically run along the pectoralis minor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a modified radical mastectomy, the medial pectoral nerve runs on the pectoralis minor muscle, distinguishing it from other nerves that are positioned on different muscles in the thoracic region.

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

 

Retrocaval ureter is a rare congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava (IVC) and gets compressed, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis. This condition does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis because it only affects the right ureter.

 

Retrocaval ureter, also known as circumcaval ureter, is a condition where the right ureter passes behind the IVC, causing compression and right-sided hydronephrosis, but it does not affect the left ureter, thus not leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phimosis: Phimosis, a condition where the foreskin cannot be fully retracted over the glans penis, can lead to urinary retention and subsequent bilateral hydronephrosis if severe and left untreated.

 

Option B. Urethral Stricture: A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra which can obstruct urine flow and cause bilateral hydronephrosis if the obstruction is significant and near the bladder neck or urethra.

 

Option C. Posterior urethral valve: Posterior urethral valves are congenital obstructive membranes in the posterior male urethra. They cause significant obstruction, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retrocaval ureter is a condition that affects only the right ureter, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allograft

 

Explanation:

 

An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autograft: An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.

 

Option D. Isograft: An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth, which appears bluish-red and transilluminates positively. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ranula

 

A ranula is a type of mucous cyst that forms in the floor of the mouth. It typically presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling that transilluminates positively due to its fluid content. Ranulas are caused by the obstruction of salivary glands, leading to the accumulation of mucous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: This is incorrect because dermoid cysts contain sebaceous material and hair, and they do not transilluminate. They are also not typically bluish-red in appearance.

 

Option C. Sublingual growth: This is incorrect as a general term that does not specify a cystic or transilluminating nature.

 

Option D. Sublingual cyst: This is incorrect as it does not have transillumination and bluish-red color.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth that transilluminates positively, due to the accumulation of mucous from an obstructed salivary gland.

questions.text: Identify the pathology? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The chest X-ray in the image shows air under the diaphragm, which is indicative of perforation peritonitis. This condition, commonly referred to as a hollow viscus perforation, occurs when there is a hole in the gastrointestinal tract, allowing air to escape into the peritoneal cavity. The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a classic sign of this condition. The treatment of choice involves fluid resuscitation of the patient, intravenous antibiotics, and emergency laparotomy.

 

The hallmark radiographic finding for a hollow viscus perforation is "free air" or "air under the diaphragm" on an erect chest X-ray or abdominal X-ray. This sign indicates the escape of air from a perforated gastrointestinal organ into the peritoneal cavity, necessitating urgent surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is typically diagnosed with clinical findings and imaging such as a CT scan of the abdomen. On imaging, the pancreas may appear swollen, and there might be evidence of associated complications like pancreatic necrosis or fluid collections. However, air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic feature of acute pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is usually identified on imaging modalities like ultrasound or CT scan, showing a well-defined hypoechoic or cystic lesion within the liver. The presence of air under the diaphragm is not associated with liver abscess.

 

Option C. Acute cholecystitis: Acute cholecystitis is primarily diagnosed using ultrasound, which would show a thickened gallbladder wall, pericholecystic fluid, and possible gallstones. Air under the diaphragm is not a typical finding in acute cholecystitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is indicative of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient has undergone surgery as shown in the image below.  After this surgery, the patient presents with pallor, dizziness and sweating whenever he has a large meal. What could this be? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dumping syndrome

 

In a patient following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, who develop pallor, dizziness and sweating after a large meal, dumping syndrome is most likely.

 

Dumping syndrome is complication following gastric reconstructions and vagotomy

 

Dumping syndrome is of two types

 

  • Early dumping syndrome 
    1. Occurs due to rapid influx of fluid due to hyperosmolar contents in bowel
    2. Starts within 10 mins of meals intake
    3. Clinical features: epigastric fullness, bloating, nausea & vomiting, symptoms of hypotension: light-headedness, fainting
  • Late dumping syndrome
    1. Sweating, tachycardia, dizziness after 45 mins to 1 hour of eating food
    2. Worsens with exercise
    3. It is due to rebound hypoglycemia seen due to excessive Insulin release

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reflux gastritis presents with heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain.

 

Option C. Post-vagotomy diarrhea presents with loose watery stools, increased frequency of bowel movements and abdominal cramps.

 

Option D. Freys syndrome presents with gustatory sweating. It is seen after parotid surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dumping syndrome, a common complication following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, presents with pallor, dizziness, and sweating after a large meal due to rapid influx of fluid and hyperosmolar contents in the bowel.

questions.text: Meckels diverticulum is a derivative of which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Vitellointestinal duct

 

Explanation: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct (also called vitelline duct, yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct). During embryonic development, the midgut communicates with the yolk sac through the vitellointestinal duct. Normally, this duct obliterates completely by the 7th week of development, but when the proximal part persists, it forms Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Allantoic diverticulum: This is a ventral projection of hindgut into the connecting stalk. Its proximal part gets incorporated into the apex of urinary bladder and its distal part undergoes fibrosis to form urachus. It has no relation to Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option C. Ventral mesogastrium: This is the embryological structure from which the lesser omentum and falciform ligament develop. It has no association with Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option D. Ductus arteriosus: This is a vascular structure derived from the 6th aortic arch that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal life. After birth, it obliterates to form the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum follows the "rule of 2s" - it affects 2% of population, is about 2 inches long, occurs 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, is twice as common in males, and only 2% of patients are symptomatic.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, with imaging indicating a tumor size less than 4 cm, what would be the most suitable initial treatment approach for this patient's condition among the following options? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

 

For tumors less than 4 cm, the recommended procedure is a partial nephrectomy, also known as nephron-sparing surgery.

 

  • This procedure involves removing the tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue surrounding it while leaving the remainder of the kidney intact. It is the recommended treatment for smaller renal tumors, typically less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a tumors). For the 56-year-old patient with a renal tumor less than 4 cm, partial nephrectomy is the preferred initial treatment approach as it aims to treat the cancer while preserving as much kidney function as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial nephrectomy + neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is generally resistant to chemotherapy, making this option less relevant for the patient's situation given the size of the tumor.

 

Option C. Radical nephrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of the entire affected kidney, the adrenal gland above the kidney, surrounding fatty tissue, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes. It is the preferred treatment for larger tumors or those that have started to spread outside the kidney. For a tumor less than 4 cm, and with no indication of it having spread, a radical nephrectomy may be more aggressive than necessary.

 

Option D. Radical nephrectomy + postoperative radiotherapy: Renal cell carcinomas are resistant to radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial nephrectomy is the recommended initial treatment for renal cell carcinoma tumors less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a), as it aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much kidney function as possible. This approach balances oncological control with the preservation of renal function.

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about Crohns disease?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection

 

Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. The recurrence of Crohn's disease after surgery is common, and the likelihood of relapse may depend on the extent of disease involvement, the type of surgery performed, and other individual factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

Option C. The distal ileum is a common site of involvement in Crohn's disease, but the disease can affect any part of the digestive tract from the mouth to the anus. In addition to the ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, and perianal region.

 

Option D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical resection in Crohn's disease does not cure the condition, and symptomatic relapse can occur independently of the presence of disease at the resection margins.

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondrium

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of projectile vomiting and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals an abdominal mass in the epigastrium, and the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is suspected. An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. During feeding

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a condition where the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and thickened. This leads to gastric outlet obstruction and symptoms such as projectile vomiting, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.

 

True. During feeding, or immediately after, the thickened muscle of the pylorus might be most palpable. As the stomach tries to empty its contents through the narrowed pylorus, the hypertrophied muscle can contract and become more prominent. This is called the "olive-like mass" which is palpable in the epigastrium to the right of the midline. This sign is pathognomonic for CHPS. The act of feeding induces peristaltic waves in the stomach, making the pyloric mass more prominent and easier to palpate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Soon after birth: CHPS typically presents in the third to fifth week of life, although it can be present at birth. It is rare to palpate the mass immediately after birth. The symptoms usually progress, and the hypertrophic pylorus becomes more palpable as the condition worsens.

 

Option C. During palpation, over the left hypochondrium: The pylorus is located on the right side of the abdomen, so palpating the left hypochondrium wouldn't help in detecting a mass related to CHPS.

 

Option D. During palpation, over the epigastrium: While the hypertrophied pyloric muscle can indeed be felt in the epigastrium, its palpability becomes much more distinct during or after feeding due to the reasons mentioned in option A. The epigastrium is the upper central region of the abdomen and is the location where the "olive-like mass" of CHPS is most frequently palpated.

 

Educational Objective:


In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the characteristic "olive-like mass" is most easily palpated during or immediately after feeding when the stomach contracts against the hypertrophied pyloric muscle.
