questions.text: An adult male presented to the OPD with a swelling in the scrotum which was painful. The patient was having fever as well. The swelling was in relation to the tunica vaginalis and fluid collection was present. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocele

 

The patient presents with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is noted to be in relation to the tunica vaginalis with fluid collection, which points towards a secondary hydrocele due to an underlying condition.

 

The combination of painful scrotal swelling and fever is indicative of an inflammatory or infectious process, most commonly acute epididymo-orchitis. This condition is inflammation of the epididymis and testicle, often caused by bacterial infection. The presence of fluid around the testicle, known as a hydrocele, is a secondary response to the inflammation.

 

A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. Secondary hydroceles can develop in response to infections, injuries, or inflammatory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicocele: This is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum (the pampiniform plexus). It is typically not associated with fever or acute pain and does not involve fluid collection related to the tunica vaginalis.

 

Option C. Cystocele: This condition involves the bladder bulging into the vaginal space and is unrelated to scrotal swelling.

 

Option D. Torsion testis: Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to severe pain and swelling. While torsion can occur in adults, it is more common in adolescents. It usually does not present with fever unless secondary infection occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful scrotal swelling with fever and fluid collection in an adult male, particularly in relation to the tunica vaginalis, suggests a diagnosis of secondary hydrocele due to epididymo-orchitis.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration is shown. Identify the pathology. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Testicular torsion

 

The correct answer is Testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord, which supplies blood to the testicle, becomes twisted, cutting off the blood supply. This condition presents with acute scrotal pain and is a surgical emergency. The intra-operative image shows a discolored and non-viable testis, which is characteristic of testicular torsion. Exploration in such cases is mandatory to assess the viability of the testis and to perform detorsion or orchiectomy if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsion of testicular appendage: Torsion of the testicular appendage, a small vestigial remnant located at the superior pole of the testis, is a self-limiting condition and does not usually necessitate surgical exploration. The testis in such cases remains normal, and the main feature is localized pain without the full testicular involvement seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Torsion of both: It is highly unlikely for both the testis and the appendage to undergo torsion simultaneously as they are separate anatomical structures. Thus, the option of torsion of both is not realistic.

 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: A testicular hematoma would present as swelling due to bleeding within the testicular parenchyma or surrounding tissue, often following trauma. The appearance would not match the twisted and non-viable look of the testis shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion presents as acute testicular pain and requires urgent surgical intervention. The characteristic appearance on exploration includes a discolored, possibly non-viable testis due to the loss of blood supply.

questions.text: The following condition is seen in: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis

 

Based on the provided chest X-ray, which shows numerous rounded opacities throughout the lung fields.

 

This would appear on an X-ray as multiple well-circumscribed nodules scattered throughout the lung fields known as Cannon-ball metastasis. The pattern seen in the image provided is consistent with lung metastasis, where the primary cancer elsewhere in the body has spread to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Miliary TB: This is characterized by numerous small nodules throughout the lung parenchyma resembling millet seeds, hence the term "miliary." These nodules are usually uniform in size.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: Depending on the stage, aspergillosis can present with various radiographic appearances, from a 'fungal ball' within a pre-existing cavity (aspergilloma) to invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, which typically presents with consolidation and/or nodules, often with a halo sign.

 

Option C. Consolidation: This refers to an area of the lung where alveolar air is replaced by fluid, cells, or other substances, which on an X-ray appears as a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal density. The borders of the affected area are usually indistinct and not nodular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chest X-ray findings of multiple well-circumscribed nodules throughout the lung fields are indicative of lung metastasis, representing the spread of cancer from another part of the body to the lungs.

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

 

BIRADS 2 is used for benign findings. Given that the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a well-recognized benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most suitable category for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: BIRADS 1 is assigned to a category when there is no suspicion of malignancy, and BIRADS 2 is used when there is a benign finding. In this case, since the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most appropriate category.

 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 4: BIRADS 4 is used when there is a suspicious abnormality that may or may not be cancerous. Since the histology in this case indicates a fibroadenoma appearance, which is benign, BIRADS 4 would not be appropriate.

 

Option C. BIRADS 2, 3, or 4: BIRADS 3 is assigned when there is a probably benign finding that requires short-term follow-up. In this case, since the histology indicates a fibroadenoma appearance (a benign finding), BIRADS 3 and BIRADS 4 would not be applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.

 

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.

 

Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

questions.text: 35-year-old male presented with a swelling in the scrotum for which surgical removal was done as shown. Which of the following has the best prognosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminoma

 

Seminoma is a type of testicular cancer that typically occurs in young and middle-aged men. It is known for its excellent prognosis, primarily because it is highly sensitive to radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Seminomas usually metastasize to the lymph nodes rather than spreading hematogenously, which makes them more manageable and treatable. The overall survival rate for patients with seminoma is very high due to these factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratoma: Teratomas are testicular tumors that can contain several types of tissues and may have variable behavior. While some teratomas can be benign, others can be malignant and more challenging to treat than seminomas.

 

Option C. Yolk sac tumor: Also known as endodermal sinus tumor, this is a malignant germ cell tumor more commonly seen in children. In adults, yolk sac tumors tend to have a poorer prognosis compared to seminomas.

 

Option D. Leydig cell Tumor: These tumors arise from the Leydig cells in the testes. While many Leydig cell tumors are benign, the malignant ones can be more aggressive and harder to treat than seminomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminomas have the best prognosis among testicular tumors due to their high sensitivity to radiotherapy and chemotherapy and their typically limited pattern of spread to lymph nodes.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

choices.text: Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

questions.text: A patient who had kidney stones removed presents with flank pain 4-5 years postoperatively and a foreign body is observed on imaging. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

 

The patient presents with flank pain years after having kidney stones removed, and imaging reveals a foreign body, likely a retained double J ureteric stent. Double J stents are often placed during procedures to manage kidney or ureteric stones to ensure urine drainage but should be removed once they are no longer needed.

 

The appropriate management in this case is to perform an endoscopy to remove the retained stent. Retaining a stent for too long can cause complications such as stone formation on the stent, obstruction, or infection, which explains the patient's current symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy and Cystoscopic removal: Not required in this situation

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is incorrect as it is used to assess the urethra, not the ureter or kidneys. It is used for diagnosing urethral strictures or ruptures.

 

Option D. Leave the foreign body inside: This is incorrect and not a viable option as the foreign body (stent) is causing symptoms and potential complications, and must be removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopy is the appropriate procedure for the removal of a retained ureteric stent, which can cause complications if left inside the body for too long.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.

questions.text: A patient gets a surgical removal of foreign body from stomach. The foreign body is shown in the below given image. Whom should this patient be referred to? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychiatrist

 

The picture given above is of a trichobezoar, a mass composed of ingested hair, often associated with trichotillomania (compulsive hair pulling) and trichophagia (compulsive eating of hair). These conditions are psychiatric disorders that require proper mental health management. After the surgical removal of the trichobezoar, it is crucial to address the underlying behavioral issue to prevent recurrence. Therefore, referral to a psychiatrist is essential to manage and treat the underlying compulsion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pediatrician: While a pediatrician may be involved if the patient is a child, the primary issue in this case is a psychiatric disorder requiring specialized mental health treatment.

 

Option C. Cardiologist: A cardiologist specializes in heart-related conditions and is not relevant to the treatment of trichobezoars or underlying psychiatric conditions.

 

Option D. Dermatologist: Although dermatologists treat skin and hair conditions, the compulsive behavior leading to trichobezoar formation is psychiatric in nature, requiring intervention from a mental health professional rather than a dermatologist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After the surgical removal of a trichobezoar, patients should be referred to a psychiatrist to address underlying psychiatric conditions like trichotillomania and trichophagia to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A homosexual man presented with painful defecation, foul-smelling protruding mass through anus which is non-reducible. Biopsy of the mass shows squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What will be the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiation

 

For a patient diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, the first line of management is chemoradiation (called the Nigro regimen). This approach provides good tumor control, preserves the anal sphincter function, and avoids a permanent colostomy. If chemoradiation fails or if there's a recurrence, surgical interventions like APR might be considered.

 

  • This is a combination treatment modality that uses both chemotherapy and radiation therapy to treat cancer. Chemoradiation is the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. It provides both local control of the tumor and treats potential microscopic disease. The Nigro regimen, combining 5-FU with mitomycin C or cisplatin and external beam radiation, has shown excellent results in treating this cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colostomy: Colostomy might be used as a temporary or permanent measure in cases where the anus or rectum is obstructed or needs to be bypassed. It's not the primary treatment for anal squamous cell carcinoma but may be used in certain situations to manage symptoms or complications.

 

Option C. Excision: While excision could be considered for some tumors, for anal squamous cell carcinoma, simple excision might not offer the best oncological outcomes compared to chemoradiation. Excision alone without addressing potential microscopic disease can lead to recurrence.

 

Option D. Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): This is a surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon are removed. It results in a permanent colostomy. Abdominoperineal resection was historically the treatment for anal cancer. However, with the success of chemoradiation in treating squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal, APR is now reserved for those who don't respond to chemoradiation or have recurrent disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is chemoradiation, which preserves anal sphincter function and avoids the need for a permanent colostomy.

choices.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery
It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

 

Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It can spread through both hematogenous routes and lymphatics, and treatment typically involves a combination of surgery and chemotherapy. However, while it is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, it is not the most common. That distinction belongs to neuroblastoma.

 

It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children: This statement is incorrect. While Wilms tumor is a common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in pediatric patients is neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spread by lymphatics: Nephroblastoma can spread via lymphatics, usually involving regional lymph nodes first. Although hematogenous spread is more common, lymphatic spread does occur.

 

Option B. Early lung metastasis: Wilms tumor often metastasizes to the lungs early in its course. Children diagnosed with Wilms tumor typically undergo chest imaging to check for lung metastasis.

 

Option C. Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery: The standard treatment for Wilms tumor involves surgical removal of the tumor followed by chemotherapy to eliminate any remaining cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroblastoma is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, not Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in damage control surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach that involves minimal intervention to stabilize the patient and perform definitive surgery later. The focus of DCS is on hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and limiting contamination. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving vascular anastomosis may be performed.

 

Vascular anastomosis is not typically included in damage control surgery.

 

Vascular anastomosis, is generally not performed during the initial phase of damage control surgery. Damage control surgery prioritizes addressing life-threatening injuries and stabilizing the patient. Complex procedures like vascular anastomosis are typically deferred to later, definitive surgery, after the patient's condition has been stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage control: Hemorrhage control is a critical component of damage control surgery. The primary goal of damage control surgery is to address life-threatening bleeding and stop any ongoing hemorrhage. Surgeons often use various techniques, such as packing wounds or applying temporary closures, to achieve hemorrhage control during the initial phase of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Resuscitation is a key aspect of damage control surgery. Patients who require damage control surgery are often in a state of shock due to significant blood loss and trauma. Resuscitation involves stabilizing the patient's condition by providing fluids, blood products, and other supportive measures to restore blood volume and vital organ function. It is usually done in ICU after hemorrhage is stopped.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Decontamination may be necessary in specific situations, such as chemical or biological contamination, gross spillage into peritoneum or dirty wounds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

vascular anastomosis (option D) is not a standard part of damage control surgery, while the other options (A, B, and C) are relevant components of this surgical approach.
